items.content_html: I’m fundraising for Wiltshire Ride + Stride this coming Saturday. Ride + Stride raises money for Wiltshire’s Churches. Half the money donated goes to the participant’s chosen church, and the other half is used by the Wiltshire Historic Churches Trust in grants to churches for repairs and preservation. Check out my @JustGiving page and please donate if you can. Thank you! ğŸš´â€
items.content_text:
I'm fundraising for Wiltshire Ride + Stride this coming Saturday. Ride + Stride raises money for Wiltshire's Churches. Half the money donated goes to the participant's chosen church, and the other half is used by the Wiltshire Historic Churches Trust in grants to churches for repairs and preservation.
Check out my @JustGiving page and [please donate](https://bit.ly/rideandstride2021) if you can. Thank you!  ğŸš´â€

items.content_html:
Finished reading: How to Lose a Country: The 7 Steps from Democracy to Dictatorship by Ece Temelkuran ğŸ“š

How to Lose a Country is an impassioned plea, a warning to the world that populism and nationalism donâ€™t march fully-formed into government; they creep. There’s a lot about post-Brexit England that I recognised in the book that should concern us all.

As one of the panellists, I smiled bitterly as I thought about how all these brilliant journalists were yet to suffer the despair of realising that their tactics were akin to playing chess against a pigeon, as someone once described debating evolution with a creationist: the pigeon will just knock over all the pieces and shit on the board, then depart, proudly claiming victory and leaving the mess behind for you to clean up.
items.content_text:
Finished reading: [How to Lose a Country: The 7 Steps from Democracy to Dictatorship](https://micro.blog/books/9780008294045) by Ece Temelkuran ğŸ“š 

_How to Lose a Country_ is an impassioned plea, a warning to the world that populism and nationalism donâ€™t march fully-formed into government; they creep. There's a lot about post-Brexit England that I recognised in the book that should concern us all.

>As one of the panellists, I smiled bitterly as I thought about how all these brilliant journalists were yet to suffer the despair of realising that their tactics were akin to playing chess against a pigeon, as someone once described debating evolution with a creationist: the pigeon will just knock over all the pieces and shit on the board, then depart, proudly claiming victory and leaving the mess behind for you to clean up.

items.title: Goodbye Spotify, Hello Tidal
items.content_html: After the 14 day Tidal trial, it was time to decide to stay with Spotify or move to Tidal. I prefer the new music suggestions that Spotify presents, but much prefer the UI of Tidal. Iâ€™ve also got fed up waiting for Spotify to deliver the promised HiFi streaming functionality, which is important to me as I have a Naim streamer that is capable of making good use of the hi-res delivered by Tidal. You guessed it, Iâ€™ve moved to Tidal.
items.content_text: After the 14 day Tidal trial, it was time to decide to stay with Spotify or move to Tidal. I prefer the new music suggestions that Spotify presents, but much prefer the UI of Tidal. Iâ€™ve also got fed up waiting for Spotify to deliver the promised HiFi streaming functionality, which is important to me as I have a Naim streamer that is capable of making good use of the hi-res delivered by Tidal. You guessed it, Iâ€™ve moved to Tidal.

items.title: Spotify or Tidal?
items.content_html:
Iâ€™ve flipped between both over the years, but currently using Spotify as I got a free six-month subscription when I bought a Sonos sound bar before Christmas. Thatâ€™s about to expire, and itâ€™s time to stump up Â£9.99 a month.

The question is, should I go back to Tidal or stick where I am?

I listen to music on my MacBook, iPad, my phone and a couple of Sonos speakers located throughout the house. We also have a Naim streamer in the lounge, which means that I can make the best use of a high-quality source as provided by Tidalâ€™s HiFi tier.

Spotify uses its Connect technology to send music to the Naim, whereas Tidal integrates with the Naim app, making for a more involved experience.

The only way to solve the puzzle is to have a sound off, play the same track on Spotify and Tidal and check whether I can hear a difference between the two to justify paying Â£20 a month for Tidal.

Iâ€™ve signed up for a 30-day Tidal trial. Let the games begin!

ğŸµ
items.content_text:
Iâ€™ve flipped between both over the years, but currently using Spotify as I got a free six-month subscription when I bought a Sonos sound bar before Christmas. Thatâ€™s about to expire, and itâ€™s time to stump up Â£9.99 a month.

_The question is, should I go back to Tidal or stick where I am?_

I listen to music on my MacBook, iPad, my phone and a couple of Sonos speakers located throughout the house. We also have a Naim streamer in the lounge, which means that I can make the best use of a high-quality source as provided by Tidalâ€™s HiFi tier.

Spotify uses its Connect technology to send music to the Naim, whereas Tidal integrates with the Naim app, making for a more involved experience.

The only way to solve the puzzle is to have a sound off, play the same track on Spotify and Tidal and check whether I can hear a difference between the two to justify paying Â£20 a month for Tidal.

Iâ€™ve signed up for a 30-day Tidal trial. Let the games begin!

ğŸµ

items.content_html:
Goodbye Evernote, hello Craft. I’ve done what I thought was unthinkable. After using Evernote for over a dozen years, I just cancelled my subscription and started using Craft as my full time note taking application. I tried to stay loyal to Evernote, but feel they are slipping behind and I really like what the team at Craft are doing. All that’s missing are tables (on the way) and a web clipper, also on the development list.

ğŸ“
items.content_text:
**Goodbye Evernote, hello Craft.** I've done what I thought was unthinkable. After using Evernote for over a dozen years, I just cancelled my subscription and started using [Craft](https://www.craft.do/) as my full time note taking application. I tried to stay loyal to Evernote, but feel they are slipping behind and I really like what the team at Craft are doing. All that's missing are tables (on the way) and a web clipper, also on the development list.

ğŸ“

items.content_html:
Lunchtime!

I took this using my Sony a6300 and 16-70mm lens at 70mm. The camera was connected to my iPad via WiFi and I used the Sony app to remotely fire the shutter. The shot was hampered by the short lens and the WiFi signal, which meant i had to position the camera further away from the feeder than was optimum.

ğŸ“·
items.content_text:
Lunchtime!

I took this using my Sony a6300 and 16-70mm lens at 70mm. The camera was connected to my iPad via WiFi and I used the Sony app to remotely fire the shutter. The shot was hampered by the short lens and the WiFi signal, which meant i had to position the camera further away from the feeder than was optimum.

items.title: Moved to Micro.blog
items.content_html:
Iâ€™ve just completed the signup process for a Micro.blog subscription and will be moving some posts from my old WordPress site across to micro.blog over the coming days.

Iâ€™ve decided to use the Arabica theme for the web and have made a couple of small changes to the Archive page, to keep links looking the same across the site â€” I didnâ€™t like the Nav bar looking and behaving different from the Categories on the Archive page. I just need to work out how to get the Categories to display horizontally now. I tried to use CSS to style them, but whilst I can change colours, etc., â€œdisplay: inlineâ€ doesnâ€™t work as you’ll see below.

Happy to take advice from anyone who has more experience using CSS than I do â€” whichâ€™ll be pretty much everyone.

My next challenge is to style the dates on the Archive page to look like the dates on the rest of the theme.

Still to do:

  1. Decide whether to keep my old domain name and transfer it to Micro.blog

Oh, by the way, this post was written in Ulysses and published direct to the blog.
items.content_text: Iâ€™ve just completed the signup process for a Micro.blog subscription and will be moving some posts from my old WordPress site across to micro.blog over the coming days. Iâ€™ve decided to use the Arabica theme for the web and have made a couple of small changes to the Archive page, to keep links looking the same across the site â€” I didnâ€™t like the Nav bar looking and behaving different from the Categories on the Archive page. I just need to work out how to get the Categories to display horizontally now. I tried to use CSS to style them, but whilst I can change colours, etc., â€œdisplay: inlineâ€ doesnâ€™t work as you'll see below. Happy to take advice from anyone who has more experience using CSS than I do â€” whichâ€™ll be pretty much everyone. My next challenge is to style the dates on the Archive page to look like the dates on the rest of the theme. Still to do: 1. Decide whether to keep my old domain name and transfer it to Micro.blog Oh, by the way, this post was written in Ulysses and published direct to the blog.

items.title: Working with Ulysses & Micro.blog
items.content_html:
I have recently started to use Ulysses for all my long and short-form writing and was intrigued to read that the authors added the ability to publish to micro.blog in the latest release.

I built my website on WordPress using the Extra theme and Divi builder from Elegant Themes. Whilst Iâ€™m happy with the features and functionality that Extra & Divi provides, itâ€™s difficult to justify the annual cost of around Â£85 a year for a hobby blog.

Ulysses posts to WordPress but the formatting doesnâ€™t work with the Extra theme, so wasnâ€™t really a viable option. This limitation, coupled with the cost, were the reasons behind why I was looking for an alternative blogging platform.

Setting up Ulysses to post to micro.blog was simple and took less than a minute. Exporting to micro.blog is also straightforward â€” you just select â€œPublishingâ€ as the export option and select the blog to post to, itâ€™s status (draft, publish or schedule when itâ€™s posted) and choose a category.
ğŸ“
items.content_text:
I have recently started to use [Ulysses](https://ulysses.app/ "Ulysses app") for all my long and short-form writing and was intrigued to read that the authors added the ability to publish to micro.blog in the latest release. I built my [website](https://keithpound.com/ "KeithPound.com") on WordPress using the Extra theme and Divi builder from [Elegant Themes](https://www.elegantthemes.com/ "Elegant Themes site"). Whilst Iâ€™m happy with the features and functionality that Extra & Divi provides, itâ€™s difficult to justify the annual cost of around Â£85 a year for a hobby blog. Ulysses posts to WordPress but the formatting doesnâ€™t work with the Extra theme, so wasnâ€™t really a viable option. This limitation, coupled with the cost, were the reasons behind why I was looking for an alternative blogging platform. Setting up Ulysses to post to micro.blog was simple and took less than a minute. Exporting to micro.blog is also straightforward â€” you just select â€œPublishingâ€ as the export option and select the blog to post to, itâ€™s status (draft, publish or schedule when itâ€™s posted) and choose a category.
ğŸ“

items.title: Monday Music Mix: Best of 2020
items.content_html:
It’s been a tough year for us all, but many artists released some great new music during 2020. I’ve listened to dozens of new albums, and this playlist includes some of what I thought was the best tracks.

My Album of the Year had to be Letter to You from Bruce Springsteen.

I hope you enjoy some of the tracks I’ve chosen. Leave a comment with your suggestions.

Â See you in 2021!

items.title: 12 Go-To Albums
items.content_html:
One of my ITfM Radio colleagues challenged his Facebook buddies to list their top 12 go-to albums recently. The aim was not to overthink the list, but to put down whatever came to mind.

That was never going to happen and it took me about a week to come up with this list.

My top 12 Go-To Albums

  1. Yes - Relayer
  2. Bruce Springsteen - The River
  3. Elbow - The Takeoff and Landing of Everything
  4. Frazey Ford - Indian Ocean
  5. Led Zeppelin - Physical Graffiti
  6. Anathema - Distant Satellites
  7. Darius Rucker - True Believers
  8. Dwight Yoakam - Blame the Vain
  9. Bob Harris Presents Vol 2
  10. Muse - Absolution
  11. Ryan Adams - Gold
  12. Genesis - The Lamb Lies Down on Broadway

I’ve included links to the album on Spotify where available so that you can listen to my top 12 go-to albums. I’m sure that you wont agree with my choices, but try to pick your top 12 …. its harder than you think it will be.

ğŸ¶

One of my ITfM Radio colleagues challenged his Facebook buddies to list their top 12 go-to albums recently. The aim was not to overthink the list, but to put down whatever came to mind.

That was never going to happen and it took me about a week to come up with this list.

My top 12 Go-To Albums
  1. Yes - Relayer
  2. Bruce Springsteen - The River
  3. Elbow - The Takeoff and Landing of Everything
  4. Frazey Ford - Indian Ocean
  5. Led Zeppelin - Physical Graffiti
  6. Anathema - Distant Satellites
  7. Darius Rucker - True Believers
  8. Dwight Yoakam - Blame the Vain

I've included links to the album on Spotify where available so that you can listen to my top 12 go-to albums. I'm sure that you wont agree with my choices, but try to pick your top 12 .... its harder than you think it will be.
